title: Media Queries: resolution feature
description: Allows to query the device pixel count per CSS unit
notes: Old and not recommended by W3C syntax like `-``webkit`/`moz`/`o`/`-``min`/`max``-``device-pixel-ratio` is widely supported but you need to know that now it will be deprecated so you need to add `min`/`max``-``resolution` everytime when you use this rule.

notes_by_num.1: “Implemented since IE9 along with dpi unit. It currently lacks dppx and dpcm units.” – [Chromium Dashboard](https://www.chromestatus.com/features/5944509615570944)
notes_by_num.3: Works with `-o-``min`/`max``-``device-pixel-ratio` in Presto 2.1.2 (Opera 9, Opera Mobile 9.x, Opera Mini 5, see [Presto version history](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Presto_(layout_engine))) – [CSS Device Adaptation (viewport) support in Opera Presto
notes_by_num.5: If you look at the [bug in Android Google Code issue tracker](https://code.google.com/p/android/issues/detail?id=61929) you can decide what Resolution Media Query works the same that provided in old Webkits – `-webkit-``min`/`max``-``device-pixel-ratio`
notes_by_num.6: Released in 2010, [BlackBerry OS 6](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/BlackBerry_OS#6.0) builtin web browser based on Webkit at least 531.22.7 (depending on [Safari 4](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Safari_version_history#Mac) released on March 11, 2010), so I
notes_by_num.7: Opera Mobile 11+ based on Chromium and stopped in developing in 2012, so it uses at least WebKit 531.22.7 (depending on [Safari 4](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Safari_version_history#Mac) released on March 11, 2010), so I think it can use at least prefixe
